summary.title: Database Systems
summary.description: This course covers methods for designing relational databases, the use of SQL to define and access a database, and the use of a production-level database management system to implement a relational database system. Students are required to complete a project in which they either implement a real-world example relational database, or (at the instructor's discretion and approval) research a specific database topic not covered during the class. Additional topics that may be discussed as time and class interest permit include: integrating databases into applications or web sites; alternative database paradigms; database design/engineering tools; and underlying implementation of databases.

course-outcomes.outcome: Implement a relational database of significant complexity.
Develop a database from a given set of specifications.
Model a database using Object Role Modeling.
Correctly generate and execute a wide variety of SQL commands.
Use a programming language to interface to a DBMS (embedded SQL).
Implement web based data entry and query features in a database.
Deliver an oral presentation on a completed database project.

course-content.topic: Complex SELECT queries (joins, subselects, correlated subselects).
Student Projects and guest lecturers on advanced topics.

laboratory-studio-outcomes.summary: The laboratory provides an opportunity for students to become competent with a variety of modern database tools. The development and presentation of a large project is the capstone experience for this course.

laboratory-studio-content.topic: Student Projects (approved by instructor) (4 weeks) (guest lecturers may be brought in during this time to present advanced database topics).
